overview_of_class:
322-0 Sec. 20 RTVF Genre: Race, History, and the Biopic

In this course, students will consider the biographical film or "biopic," as a genre, and proceed from the assertion that this class of motion picture carries a distinct significance for African American audiences. What sorts of aesthetic, historical and political questions and problems arise given the issues of scarcity and distortion that routinely affect black representations in mainstream media texts? How does the popularity of biopics intersect with the desire for a more complete and accurate rendering of American history that results from such longstanding diminishment? Likewise, given the significance of biopics as consistent?yet intermittent?sources of employment for underemployed African American actors, how can we map these movies onto the emergence of significant black stars, and within larger movements of black film or American film more broadly?

Students will consider three major categories of popular biopic that chronicle the lives of African American 1) entertainers; 2) sports figures; and 3) political figures/activists. We will also explore the ways that biopics are typically called upon by African American audiences to fulfill both the cultural imperative to participate in a deeply rooted black oral tradition of storytelling, and the counter-cultural imperative to tell a story that complicates and challenges oppressive or bowdlerized versions of black life stories.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students in this course will be required to develop and demonstrate their familiarity with and mastery of the following:
· Select genre theory
· The biopic, its conventions and history
· Contemporary periods of African American filmmaking
· Standard cinematic analysis in discussion and writing

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based upon in-class participation and attendance, research projects or creative works, and in-class presentations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Sample Course Texts:
Barry Keith Grant, Film Genre: From Iconography to Ideology (Short Cuts series)
Monica White Ndounou, Shaping the Future of African American Film
Mia Mask, Divas On Screen

Students will be required to complete weekly screenings and readings; films may include Brian's Song (Buzz Kulik, 1971); Malcolm X (Spike Lee, 1992); What's Love Got to Do With It? (Brian Gibson, 1993); Talk To Me (Kasi Lemmons, 2007); Notorious (George Tillman Jr., 2009); Introducing Dorothy Dandridge (Martha Coolidge, 1999); Nina (Cynthia Mort, 2016); and Hidden Figures (Theodore Melfi, 2016).
**All films will be made available for viewing on Canvas
